gov.anl.ipns.Util.Numeric
Class arrayUtil

java.lang.Object
  gov.anl.ipns.Util.Numeric.arrayUtil

public class arrayUtil
extends java.lang.Object

This class provides static methods for some basic array operations such as reversing, finding values and extracting a portion of an array of floats.

Method Detail

Reverse

public static void Reverse(float[] arr)
Reorder the elements of the specified array in reverse order.

Parameters:
arr - The array whose elements are reversed.

get_index_of

public static int get_index_of(float x,
                               float[] x_vals)
Find a value in an array of floats that is IN INCREASING ORDER, by using a binary search.

Parameters:
x - The value to find
x_vals - The array of x values IN INCREASING ORDER.
Returns:
The last index, i, for which x_vals[i] <= x, provided that x is between x_vals[0] and x_vals[x_vals.length-1]. If the array is empty or if x is outside of the interval from x_vals[0] to x_vals[x_vals.length-1], this returns -1.

get_index_of

public static int get_index_of(int x,
                               int[] x_vals,
                               int first,
                               int last)
Find a value in an array of ints that is IN INCREASING ORDER, by using a binary search.

Parameters:
x - The value to find
x_vals - The array of x values IN INCREASING ORDER.
first - The first position to be considered in the search.
last - The last position to be considered in the search.
Returns:
The index at which x was found in the array, or -1 if x was not found.

interpolate

public static float interpolate(float x_value,
                                float[] x,
                                float[] y)
Obtain an approximate value for y(x) by interpolating using tables of values for x and y. If the x_value is outside of the interval of x values in the table, this returns the first or last y value. The table of x values must be in order and should all be distinct.

Parameters:
x_value - the x value for which the corresponding y value is to be interpolated
x - array of x values
y - array of corresponding y values. There must be at least as many y values as x values.
Returns:
interpolated y value at the specified x value

SignedAbsSum

public static float SignedAbsSum(float[] x)
Calculate the "signed absolute" total value for an array of numbers. If all the numbers have the same sign, this is just the ordinary sum. If the numbers have mixed sign, this will be the sum of the absolute values of the given numbers.

Parameters:
x - The array of numbers being "summed".
Returns:
The sum if all the numbers have the same sign, the sum of the absolute values otherwise.

SortOnX

public static void SortOnX(floatPoint2D[] points)
Sort an array of 2D points based on the x coordinates of the points. (Not implemented in Java 1.1 version. )

Parameters:
points - The array of 2D points to sort.

sort

public static void sort(int[] values)
Sort an array of integers to place them in increasing order

Parameters:
values - the array of integers to sort

swap

public static void swap(int[] list,
                        int i,
                        int j)
Interchange two integers in an array of integers, used by q_sort_ints.

Parameters:
list - the array holding the elements to interchange.
i - the index of the first element to interchange.
j - the index of the second element to interchange.

q_sort

public static void q_sort(int[] list,
                          int start,
                          int end)
Do a "quick" sort of a portion of an array of integers. This implementation of the quick sort algorithm uses the middle element of a sub-list as the key to split the sub-list. While the worst case behavior is still O(n**2), it should only occur in rare cases. The standard quick sort is O(n**2) for ordered lists, which is a very common occurence.

Parameters:
list - the array holding the list to sort.
start - the index of the start of the list to sort in the array.
end - the index of the end of the list to sort in the array.

increasing

public static boolean increasing(int[] list)
Determine whether or not an array of integers contains a strictly increasing sequence of distinct integer values.

Parameters:
list - The array of integers to check.
Returns:
True if the list is empty, or if the list contains an increasing sequence of distinct integers. Return false of if there are duplicate values, or if the list is not in increasing order.

make_increasing

public static int[] make_increasing(int[] list)
Make a list of the distinct integers occurring in an array and place them in increasing order.

Parameters:
list - The array of integers to use to build the increasing list.
Returns:
A new empty array if the list is null or empty. If the list is non-empty, the new array will be non-empty and will contain all of the distinct integer values, sorted in increasing order.

getPortion

public static float[] getPortion(float[] arr,
                                 int new_length)
Extract a sequence of elements from the given array to form a new array. If a longer array is needed, the unused positions are filled with zeros.

Parameters:
arr - the source array from which elements are extracted.
new_length - the size of the new array to be created.
Returns:
An new array filled with elements from the given array and zero padded if necessary.

getMax

public static float getMax(float[] arr)
Get the largest value in an array.

Parameters:
arr - The array in which the largest value is to be found
Returns:
The largest value in the array. If the array is empty, return Float.NEGATIVE_INFINITY

getMin

public static float getMin(float[] arr)
Get the smallest value in an array.

Parameters:
arr - The array in which the smallest value is to be found
Returns:
The smallest value in the array. If the array is empty, return Float.POSITIVE_INFINITY

getMaxStep

public static float getMaxStep(float[] arr)
Get the largest difference between successive values in an array.

Parameters:
arr - The array in which the largest step is to be found
Returns:
The largest difference between successive values in the array. If the array is empty, or if there is only one element in the array, return 0.

getMinStep

public static float getMinStep(float[] arr)
Get the smallest difference between successive values in an array.

Parameters:
arr - The array in which the smallest step is to be found
Returns:
The smallest difference between successive values in the array. If the array is empty, or if there is only one element in the array, return 0.

isUniformlySpaced

public static boolean isUniformlySpaced(float[] arr,
                                        float tol)
Check whether or not the values in an array are essentially evenly spaced to within a specified percentage. It is assumed that the values in the array are either increasing or decreasing. If max and min are the largest and smallest absolute differences between successive values, this function returns true if 100 * (max-min)/max < tol.

Parameters:
arr - The array to be checked for uniform step sizes.
tol - The tolerance for the percentage difference in step sizes.
Returns:
True if there is a non-zero step size and the step sizes are with tol% of the largest step size. Return false otherwise.

main

public static void main(java.lang.String[] argv)
Main program for testing purposes only.
